captions.text:
bjbj Episode 36: Jynx Justified Hello Internet.
Welcome to Game Theory, the gaming show with

the most smartest viewers on all the Interwebz.
Take for instance Izzy, a loyal theorist so

fueled by a mix of intense intellectual curiosity
and incredible boredom that he solved one

of gaming s most hot-button topics. For those
of you new to this rodeo, Jynx is Game Theory

s fourth-greatest arch-nemesis, just behind
Ignorance, Yarn bombers, and Bobby Chips the

Game Overthinker. For two episodes, we covered
everything from classical opera to 90 s Japanese

fashion trends to find an explanation for
her appearance. I even wrote my own Christmas

poetry in an episode that would make Bill
Shakespeare jealous. Consider this a shameless

plug to watch those episodes. To recap, in
January of 2000, while everyone else celebrated

surviving the computer uprising known as Y2K,
others rang in the birth of a new millennium

by dragging up the racial hatred of the past
thousand years, claiming that Pokemon, a kids

game produced by squeaky clean Nintendo, featured
offensive stereotypes in the black-faced,

big-lipped character of Jynx. But, despite
all my research, I was unable to decide 100%

one way or the other about Jynx s inspiration.
Enter Izzy, a veritable Fox Mulder of gaming

theorists, believing that the truth was indeed
out there and then writing in to share his

discoveries. So, today s episode is brought
to you almost entirely by this man, Izzy:

Olympic mascot, Digimon celebrity, carbonated
fruit beverage as he provides the gaming world

with what I believe to be the definitive final
answer on the infamous racist Pokemon. We

begin in Japanese folklore with the yama-uba,
or mountain crone, a supernatural monster

who cannibalistically feeds on unsuspecting
travelers, with a specific craving for children.

Yeah, that sounds like it really fits in a
game whose mascot is cuter than a kitten in

a cup. But hold on there, Joe Skeptic because
in most translations, she s described as having

long hair that is golden white. She s known
to wear around a tattered red kimono. So that

fulfills two key elements to Jynx s appearance
right off the bat. Of course, it s not a perfect

match. We re overlooking Yamauba s second
demon mouth, the one she keeps hidden under

her hair on the back of her head. Don t really
remembering that being a part of ajaynx s

design, but hey, no one s perfect except my
wife Stephanie, of course. Sorry, as a newlywed

husband, I m required to say stuff like that.
And just like a Ronco infomercial, just wait,

there s more so appearances aside, what other
similarities are there? For that, we must

go to the theatre, specifically, Noh Theater,
a form of classical Japanese musical drama

that dates back to the 14th century. So sit
back as I transport you to ancient Japan to

tell the tale of Yamanba: A female dancer,
called "Hyakuma Yamanba" embarks on a pilgrimage

accompanied by her attendants. (drums) While
travelling north-east, they arrive at a river

boundary where the road diverges in three
directions. They ask for directions from a

local (drums), who advises them that the mountain
pass is far too steep as it is the path Buddah

himself takes as he descends to receive souls.
(drums) The dancer decides that, as she is

a pilgrim, it is fitting that she proceed
on foot to take that very path (big drums).

She has not gone far when the sun sets unexpectedly,
and they are offered lodgings by a mysterious

old woman who demands that the dancer perform.
They quickly realize the old crone is the

supernatural being Yama-uba. 
The dancer dares not refuse Yama-uba's request
for fear of being eaten, but it is the Yama-uba

herself who performs the long dance which
ends the play. So aside from showing off my

mildly impressive Photoshopping and motion
graphics skills, how does this relate to Jynx?

I refer you now to Jynx s entries from the
various Pokedexes, Pokedexi, Pokedexees, throughout

the franchise s history. Pokemon Red/Blue:
It seductively wiggles its hips as it walks.

It can cause people to dance in unison with
it. Pokemon Yellow: Appears to move to a rhythm

of its own, as if it were dancing. Pokemon
Gold: It rocks its body rhythmically. It appears

to alter the rhythm depending on how it is
feeling. Pokemon Silver: It speaks a language

similar to that of humans. However, it seems
to use dancing to communicate. Pokemon Sapphire:

A JYNX sashays rhythmically as if it were
dancing. Its motions are so bouncingly alluring,

people seeing it are compelled to shake their
hips without noticing. Note the CONSTANT mention

of dancing, and little else, not its ice or
psychic abilities, not even its female appearance,

and this is throughout the whole series. Yama-uba
is also known for her seductive dance. Coincidence?

I think not. So now we have a connection to
Jynx's appearance and behavior, what about

her type Ice type? In another Noh drama, Yamauba,
Dame of the Mountain, the title character

is portrayed as a fairy ( Hey Listen ) who
decks the mountains in snow during the winter

months. And while ice powers are fine and
all, how could a cannibalistic demon possibly

be related to Christmas, like in that banned
Pokemon episode, you ask? Throughout most

of her history, yes, the Mountain Crone was
seen as a purely evil creature, but recently

she has taken on more positive aspects in
the public eye, with modern representations

of the Yama-Uba as a sort of harvest deity.
In fact, around Nagano the story goes that

Yama-Uba descends every 19th and 20th of December
carrying a magical gourd to buy large amounts

of sake. Her very presence would temporarily
cause the market value of the sake to rise.

Admittedly, a folk tale created by the sake
industry to sell more alcohol in December

is not the same as a holiday hyped up by toy
stores to sell more Tamogotchis and Pogs during

Christmas, but you gotta admit, if Jynx showed
up in the anime carrying around a bag of booze,

Nintendo would have a whole other set of controversies
on its hands. Which brings us back to the

initial question: What about the black face
and exaggerated lips? Take a look at this.

It s the costume for a Noh performer in the
role of Yama-Uba. Notice the heavy tanning

or black face? In addition, think back to
our discussion of ganguro, where Japanese

girls darken their faces to look brown. Unlike
some forms of ganguro which began as a rebellion

against tradition or a means of mimicking
black celebrities, there is actually another

variety of ganguro known as yamamba, a name
derived from Yama-uba which is, in fact, an

homage to the character of the Yama-uba. Is
Jynx racist? I feel 100% confident saying

no. Like most other Pokemon, her origins harken
back to Japanese folklore. The hair, the clothes,

the seductive wiggle and the ice powers, the
Christmas special, and most importantly, the

black face with the big lips. In the end,
the moral of the story is this: People can

make a fuss and then wait 12 years for an
online web series to find the answers for

them, or they can just do a little research
before flipping out. Ah who am I kidding?

Bring it on world! I m here to clean up the
stupidity. But hey, it s just a theory. A

Game Theory. Thanks for watching. hpGI h7k6
h7k6 hCDa h7k6 h7k6 hpGI [Content_Types].xml

5:39

That entry for Sapphire was actually from Emerald.

This is Emerald's entry:
A Jynx sashays rhythmically as if it were dancing. Its motions are so 
bouncingly alluring, people seeing it are compelled to shake their hips 
without noticing.


This is Ruby and Sapphire's entry:
Jynx walks rhythmically, swaying and shaking its hips as if it were 
dancing. Its motions are so bouncingly alluring, people seeing it are 
compelled to shake their hips without giving any thought to what they are 
doing.﻿
comments.author: Yale “Shadow the Hedgehog” Kolin

comments.text:
What I think is this: Racism isn't stereotyping. Racism as a word, and this 
is what so many people don't get, doesn't mean showing racial stereotypes. 
Stereotypes like tropes and other cultural phenomena, like Nerds wearing 
glasses or Jocks alway playing football is done to show someone fast and 
easy to udnerstand, who a character is without having to tell the audience. 
Norally it is more often used in kids shows, Pumbaa in the Lion King is fat 
and clumsy and a pig, the Witch in a Movie is ugly so kids can see who is 
weird and perhaps not with well intentions.

Racism or sexism or whatever-ism means that not only are people different 
and showing that exaggerated. It means that these people are "inferior" or 
have a "lesser quality". Racism thinks that some Races are better than 
others. Islamism thinks that Moslems are better than other people. Sexism 
thinks that Men are more intelligent... or women are more intelligent. 
Racism means, that people of other races are not entitled to the same 
rights and priviliges that the "own" race has.

Showing differences is not racism. Denying differences is stupid cause 
everyone is different. We are all different and showing that is no problem. 
But we should have the same rights and priviliges. Nobody is better or 
worth more because of race or gender or intellect or anything. That's the 
point of not being racist. And not to hide differences or not showing them.﻿

comments.text:
The problem is very often that people project the symbols of their cultur 
into expressions of other cutlurs. The blackfacing is one of the best 
examples of this problem.
There are nations where blackfacing was used in their history to make 
racist jokes against black people (I have in mind in special U.S. and for 
some extant for example the Netherlands).

Other nations instead never used this to make fun of black people. 
Traditionally these nations never importat many slaves into their boarders 
so that there were never many descendents of these slaves to make fun of. I 
am living in Germany and as far as I know, the first black people living 
here were the children of U.S. soldiers made in the after the second world 
war.
I heard about the racist conotation of blackfacing the first time when I 
heard about autrages in the U.S. because of this action. The only situation 
when a person blackens their face I knew about here in germany is an old 
tradition on Epiphany when three children walk from door to door, blessing 
the houses while they are dressed as the three kings. Since one of the 
three kings was black, they honor him by putting ash or other black paint 
into the face of this boy.

You see the diference: U.S. blackfacing to ridicule, Germany (for example) 
= blackfacing to remember that one of the three kings were black. It is 
normal that the act of painting a face black is seen completly different in 
these culturs and that it can happen that you walk during carnival into 
someone with a blackened face, making party in the streets. It is not seen 
as a bad thing to do.

To get back to the video: You can't say something is rasist by the 
standarts of your society when you judge some product of another society 
without considering their cultur and their traditions. Maybe, something 
that offend you is ment as an honor by the other person.﻿

Adults are so fucking disgusting.
As a child whenever I looked at Mr. popo or Jynx I NEVER thought "Hah look 
a nigger". I just thought they were magical creatures or pokemon-animals or 
whatever.

Even as a 21 year old I didn't see anything bad of it. But now that they've 
changed their skin colors, it made me wonder "Why did they change their 
skin?", and I've learned that it's apparently because they previously 
portrayed black people.

Now my mind has been polluted, and I can never look at these characters the 
same way again, or any future dark skinned cartoon characters. Changing 
their colors did more harm than good, in my case. Thanks a fucking lot.﻿
comments.author: waabaakii

comments.text:
I think Jynx and Mr Popo did involve a mild dose of black facing but as 
absurd as this sounds, I doubt it was with ill-intent. I grew up in Korea 
and was well immersed in its culture, and black facing was... a common way 
to play the role of a "tribal" like character, most likely in a comedy or 
some type of play, usually depicting the character as uneducated, 
uncivilized human. But not trying to purposely degrade tribal people, but 
just in a way of playing a "uncivilized" character. Of course, it can be 
very (well it probably is very) offensive, but people of Korea wasn't 
aware, at that time, of the consequences of being racist and how ignorant 
they can be seen if they did such things in the eyes of the international 
community. Back in the early 80's and late 90's they probably threw on a 
black face to make caveman sounds to make people laugh, thinking it's 
funny. Nowadays though, you don't see any black face in any Korean media, 
because they learned that what they did was... Terribly racist. It's easy 
to be quite racist when you're born and raised in a country where you don't 
see a lot of different looking foreigners about, and the only really 
different looking foreigners you see is through the eyes of TV. But Korea 
is visited by many different foreigners these days, and being more exposed 
to other international cultures and gaining perspective. 

To put it shortly, it was a mistake, without ill-intent and better 
understanding of how the international community would react to a such 
character. People can fight for Jynx and Mr Popo's right to stay pitch 
black, but I think it was a better move to change their color to avoid 
upsetting some people... Unless... I don't know, their original color is 
absolutely vital to the plot or the game or something. Racism is such a 
sensitive issue, I think it's better to just side step.

If Nintendo (or the creator of Jynx) knew the exact details of issues 
caused by racism (and the issues that caused racism) in United States, they 
would think twice about creating a pokemon that can possibly upset and 
offend many people like that.﻿

comments.text:
I just realised... this may just be me being more out of touch with the 
world than I thought, but I haven't heard any "black" people complain about 
Kim-chan, my Jynx (because I was in an unoriginal mood and shortened the 
Japanese word used for blonde.) or the ever badass Mr Popo.

Am I just being ignorant or are people flipping their shit about racism 
faster than I go down on a vanilla shake? Someone please answer that 
question. I don't get insulted by Asian jokes, hell I MAKE them. I don't 
get pissed when people bring up the convict heritage of the majority of 
Australia. I don't even get pissed when people ask me how many times I say 
G'day in a week. If anything, I feign rage then make my own crack about 
either halves of my background.

Sorry, got off topic. So, AM I being ignorant or are people flipping their 
shit about people being racists more often than it's warranted?﻿

comments.text:
It really doesn't matter what Jynx was based on, her depiction is still 
very clearly offensive and no amount of pathetic pokemon fans crying over 
people having a problem with their childhood game is going to change the 
fact. That is real stupidity and ignorance, more so than the games 
developers who I can see wouldn't realize the significance of a character 
they were designing. But the sheer ignorance of these pathetic fans is 
sadly not that astounding. Just look at them crying because people had a 
problem with an image of a character that is clearly black face, whether 
intentional or not. And you know these are mostly ignorant white kids who 
have no idea what racism or prejudice actually is because they have never 
experienced it themselves. It was not that long ago that black face and 
fucking lynching black people was a very common thing. Hell you can get 
away with killing a black person now if you have a badge on your chest. So 
excuse the fuck out of people for being angry and offended over a character 
that very clearly looks like black face, whether intended to or not. You 
people are truly pathetic and have no say in what racism is or what people 
should or shouldn't be offended by. You do not get what it is like to deal 
with racism so stop it.﻿

comments.author: Just a Hyena, Nothing Special

comments.text:
You should not label people racists just because their choices of words and 
actions are *deemed* racist as it is completely a matter of *perspective*. 
Like it or not, what is considered as racist is not universally-accepted. 
In the US, where there is a history of discrimination against black people, 
black face is considered offensive. But, in countries where they don't have 
such history, black face does not have any racial connotation. In fact, if 
you actually think that US perspective of racism is the only right 
perspective, you are being ethnocentric as you refuse to even consider  
perspectives from other countries and cultures. Ethnocentrism is as bad as 
racism.

We should also consider the intentions of those people. If people said 
racial slurs, we really need the contexts. Did they say those slurs as they 
were really hateful? Or did they say those slurs because they were talking 
about racism and racial slurs? If it's the latter, then you cannot say they 
are racists, not even the slightest. Racists love to dehumanise other 
people. But, labeling certain people racists when you don't even bother to 
find out their intentions means you dehumanise them.﻿
